PROJECT AT A GLANCE 
 

 

 

   

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans of 
(i) up to $50,000,000 in United States (US) dollars to Arctic Green Energy Corporation Private 
Limited (AGE); and (ii) up to $200,000,000 equivalent in US dollars and yuan to Sinopec Green 
Energy  Geothermal  Development  (SGE)  for  the  Geothermal  District  Heating  Project  in  the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
The project supports private sector participation in urban district heating with geothermal 
2. 
energy in the PRC. By facilitating the delivery of clean and reliable heating services, the project 
helps mitigate air pollution. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

3. 
Heating is an important aspect of the PRC’s fight against air pollution and climate change. 
Approximately 25% of energy consumed in the country’s buildings is used to produce space heat; 
in the northern PRC, heating’s share is 50%. Heating needs are met primarily by cogeneration 
units,  household  stoves,  and  heat-only  boilers,  for  which  the  share  of  coal  as  a  feedstock  is 
approximately  80%. 1  This  has  severe  environmental  consequences,  as  particulate  matter 
produced from coal combustion is a primary cause of urban air pollution and is in turn associated 
with a range of serious health impacts and a reduction of economic output.2 Coal combustion is 
also  a  leading  source  of  greenhouse  gases  (GHGs),  of  which  the  PRC  is  the  world’s  leading 
emitter, contributing directly to global climate change. 
 
The  government  has  long  recognized  these  challenges,  and  has  placed  increasing 
4. 
attention  on  improving  the  environmental  performance  of  the  urban  heating  system.  Policies 
issued  by  the  Ministry  of  Environmental  Protection  instruct  municipalities  to  close  small-scale 
heat-only  boilers  and  promote  more  energy-efficient  technologies,  including  those  based  on 
renewable  energy.3 Among  the  various  options  for  more  environmentally  sustainable  heating, 
geothermal energy has emerged as a new government priority.4 Geothermal energy offers stable 
temperatures (appropriate for heating), generates zero emissions, can be integrated into existing 
networks with other heat sources, and is economically viable (with adequate resources). When 
extracted fluids are reinjected, geothermal energy is also renewable. 
 

 

1  International  Energy  Agency.  2015.  Building  Energy  Use  in  China:  Transforming  Construction  and  Influencing 
Consumption to 2050. Paris; and Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2013.  Low-Carbon Development in Small and 
Medium-Sized Cities in the People’s Republic of China: Challenges and Opportunities. ADB Briefs. No. 14 (June).

Promotion and Development of Geothermal Energy. Beijing; and Government of the PRC, National Development 
and Reform Commission. 2015. Enhanced Actions on Climate Change: China’s Intended Contribution. Beijing. 

 2 

 

While  low-  and  medium-temperature  geothermal-based  heating  is  commonplace  in 
5. 
Europe and other regions, until the 2010s it occupied a limited niche in the PRC.5 Constraints to 
its development have included a lack of awareness of the country’s geothermal resource potential, 
gaps in technical expertise, a lack of relevant policies to spur adoption, and limited experience in 
the efficient management of heating networks. As a result, in 2015, geothermal energy (including 
both direct heating and ground source heat pumps) accounted for only 6% of the country’s heated 
floor space. However, the PRC’s low- to medium-temperature geothermal resource base is vast 
in terms of exploitable energy—at least four times the size of its natural gas reserve base. With 
advanced  technologies  and  operational  know-how,  the  PRC’s  geothermal  resources  could  be 
harnessed on a scale that would potentially heat several hundred cities. 
 
6. 
In 2017, the government announced major initiatives to accelerate geothermal adoption 
in the heating sector. The National Energy Administration issued the country’s inaugural five year 
plan  for  geothermal  energy,  which  targets  a  tripling  of  geothermal  heating  area  to  1.1  billion 
square meters (m2) by 2020 and thereby the avoidance of 40 million tons per year of coal use.6 
The Ministry of Environmental Protection issued the Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action 
Plan,  which  calls  for  the  replacement  of  coal-fired  heating  systems  in  28  cities  in  the  greater 
Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei (BTH) region7—the country’s worst-polluted area and home to nearly 30% 
of  the  population—with  cleaner  alternatives  such  as  geothermal-based  heating  (footnote  3). 
Finally, the State Council launched the creation of a new economic zone in Xiong’an New Area, 
approximately 100 kilometers southwest of Beijing, involving the transfer of a significant portion 
of Beijing’s administrative and business activities to a new urban development of 2,000 square 
kilometers, and announced a decision to heat the area with geothermal energy.8 
 
SGE, a Sino-Icelandic joint venture, is a leading proponent of geothermal district heating 
7. 
in the PRC. SGE is 49% owned by AGE, an Iceland-affiliated geothermal energy company. SGE 
utilizes  advanced  technologies,  based  on  approaches  transferred  from  Iceland  (a  country  for 
which geothermal resources provide 69% of primary energy supply), and has a unique business 
model  spanning  upstream  and  downstream  operations.  Established  in  2006,  SGE  has  an 
operating portfolio of 25 cities and a large pipeline of identified opportunities. It collaborates with 
the government on national geothermal development plans, technology transfer and standards, 
and urban planning for Xiong’an.9 Recognizing the role of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 
supporting  the  PRC’s  environmentally  sustainable  growth,  as  well  as  its  track  record  in 
nonsovereign assistance to pioneering urban infrastructure firms, AGE and SGE requested ADB’s 
assistance to scale up SGE’s operations. 
 

2. 

Project Design 

8. 
The  project  will  support  the  construction,  acquisition,  rehabilitation,  and  operation  of  a 
series of urban district heating systems based on geothermal energy. ADB will extend financing

on a subproject-by-subproject basis, subject to defined environmental, social, development, and 
financial criteria.10 Subprojects will be identified during the project implementation stage. 
 
9. 
Each  subproject  will  involve  a  concession  or  similar  public–private  partnership  (PPP) 
arrangement  with  a  municipal  government,  under  which  SGE  would  have  exclusive  rights  to 
develop geothermal energy resources and network infrastructure, and to deliver heat and related 
services  (e.g.,  hot  water)  to  residential,  commercial,  and  industrial  end  users.  Subproject 
infrastructure to be developed includes production and reinjection wells, heat centrals, monitoring 
and control stations, and heat trunk lines.11 At each location, the specific configuration of systems 
will  depend  on  local  development  and  environmental  needs  as  determined  by  the  municipal 
governments.  Service  fees,  such  as  heat  tariffs  and  connection  fees,  will  be  set  by  SGE  and 
municipal authorities and adjusted as needed during operations.

B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Output 

15. 
Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: mitigated air pollution and GHG 
emissions in the PRC, consistent with the goals of the PRC’s Ministry of Environmental Protection 
(footnote 3). 22 
 
16. 
Outcome.  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  expanded  provision  of 
environmentally sustainable heating services, which will provide clean, reliable, safe, and high-
quality heat to urban customers, and avoid GHG emissions. 
 
17. 
Output. The output will be the construction of geothermal-based district heating systems. 
By 2021, (i) at least 20 municipal- or county-level PPPs will be developed, with the capacity to 
heat 50 million  m2  of  heated area; (ii)  at  least  CNY7.9  billion  will  be  spent  domestically  during 
construction; and (iii) at least 2,000 construction jobs will be provided.  
 
C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

18. 
Consistency with ADB strategy. The project is consistent with ADB’s Midterm Review 
of  Strategy  2020,  which  identifies  (i)  environment  and  climate  change,  (ii)  infrastructure 
development,  and  (iii)  private  sector  development  as  3  of  ADB’s  10  strategic  priorities.23 With 
regard  to  the  environment  and  climate  change,  the  project  mitigates  air  pollution  and  health 
threats  and  promotes  clean  energy.  With  regard  to  infrastructure,  the  project  is  aligned  with 
Strategy  2020’s  focus  on  environmentally  sustainable  growth.  With  regard  to  private  sector 
development, the project supports a frontier area of private sector participation.

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE

B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

ADB would add value through the following:

(i)  as  ADB’s  first  private  sector  geothermal  district  energy  project,  the  project  is

the  project  raises  standards  for  the  PRC  geothermal  industry  by  conditioning

(ii) 

(iii)  ADB’s assistance will lower transaction costs by bundling a series of subprojects in

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

25. 
In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified as 
category  B  for  environment,  category  B  for  involuntary  resettlement,  and  category  C  for 

  

7 

indigenous  peoples.29 A  corporate  audit  of  SGE  was  undertaken  by  an  external  third  party  in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements for general corporate finance. 
The audit found environmental and social impacts associated with construction and operation of 
geothermal district heating system subprojects typically involve drilling waste management and 
disposal;  tailwater  management  (where  100%  reinjection  is  not  achieved);  inadequate 
occupational  health  and  safety  monitoring  programs; 
temporary  non-major  economic 
displacement  during  well  drilling  and  pipe  laying;  and  permanent  non-major  economic 
displacement in case of heat central construction in rural villages.30 The institutional capacity and 
commitment  of  SGE  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and  environmental  impacts  are  deemed 
adequate to meet local and national requirements, but corporate-level capacity development is 
needed to meet the requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
SGE’s  existing  environmental  health  and  safety  system  (EHSS)  is  focused  on  the 
26. 
operational environment and health and safety risk management performance of geothermal well 
drilling, pipe laying and heat central operations. The EHSS meets national requirements and the 
International Organization for Standardization 14001 standard.31 The existing system does not, 
however,  cover  corporate-level  environmental  and  social  risk  and  impact  appraisal  for  new 
concessions,  measures  for  continual  improvement  (staff  training,  monitoring  and  supervision), 
grievance redressal, or reporting to stakeholders such as ADB. A value addition of the project will 
be the establishment of a corporate-level ESMS that will operate in parallel with the operational 
site-level EHSS to meet ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. SGE has committed 
to implement the ESMS prior to first disbursement. An ESMS framework has been designed in 
consultation with ADB, and is being refined with external expert assistance to meet SGE's specific 
business needs and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements.32 
 
27. 
The independent audit of SGE's operations found no indications of gender discrimination. 
SGE's  human  resource  policy  broadly  follows  that  of  the  Sinopec  Group,  which  prohibits 
discrimination of any kind, and is compliant with the PRC’s laws and regulations. Approximately 
40% of SGE's 285 direct employees are female, a share slightly above that of the Sinopec Group 
(36%).  Women  hold  approximately  27%  of  managerial  and  technical  positions  at  SGE’s 
headquarters,  including  chief  financial  officer  and  chief  technology  officer;  when  including 
operating subsidiaries, 15% of management and technical positions are held by females. Gender
